One thing I know is this. If you haven't been up close and personal around

ignorance when you say things like that.  I have not heard one verified 
driver, pitman, car owner, track employee, or knowledgeable fan speak out 
against Tony. Even if Tony spun him out on purpose which makes no sense 
either, when he had done that, there wouldn't be anymore anger. His blood 
pressure would be normal. Kevin Ward was the one that was out of control, 
not Tony. Tony has been crashed out of the all star race and cost himself a 
million dollars. Why would he ever lose his cool at a completely 
meaningless race that he was only at because the promoter wanted him there 
to sell more tickets. I have even heard people voice opinions that seem to 
think nascar is the governing body over auto racing in the US. Nascar is a 
corporation wholly owned by the France family. It stands for National 
Association of Stock Car auto Racing. It isn't even a sanctioning body.

nascar paid announcers than network and pretty much do whatever they want.﻿

To all you idiots below me who are saying it's Tony's fault...my family has 
been running 360 and 410 sprint cars all over the east coast since 1975 and 
we've seen EVERYTHING. People don't understand that sprint cars are a WHOLE 
different ballgame than any old NASCAR stock car or a regular old street 
car. Sprint car brakes are designed to swing the rear end of the car 
through the turns on these dirt tracks, hence why you always see them 
drifting through the turns and not just following the direction of the 
track like they do in NASCAR. Sprint cars only weigh 1500 lbs max. If you 
come into the turn and turn the wheel to the left, the car's inertia will 
just drag it straight. The only way to actually turn the car is to tap the 
throttle and hit the brake, which will jerk the car forward and swing the 
rear end around. Sprint cars are NOT designed to turn right, only once they 
have started sliding through the turns. The fact that the wing is low like 
they mentioned in the video has nothing to do with it. Even on a caution 
when the cars are taxiing around the track, you don't have much reaction 
time to something like a person coming onto the track. Everyone thinks Tony 
purposely cracked the throttle to run into Ward, but he was doing it while 
hitting the brake in order to swing the rear end away from Ward and avoid 
hitting him. If Tony had continued going straight, he would have completely 
run Ward over, but he only clipped the side of him. That's for all you 
idiots who didn't know jack about sprint cars until you heard about this 
accident. You can bitch and argue with me all you want, but just know that 
this is coming from 40 years of experience with dirt track racing so I know 
what I'm talking about. ﻿

Without an onboard camera or a driver POV camera, no one can say Tony 
Stewart did or did not do anything.  There is a reason the investigation is 
still ongoing, because its not obvious to anyone looking at the videos that 
it was intentional, however they also want to do their due diligence for 
the family.  Car #45 was directly in front of TS, and it is clear that KW 
approached very close to that car waiting for TS.  It is likely that he was 
shielded by car #45 and once that car passed there was less than one second 
to impact. To say one way or the other whether it was intentional is going 
to be nearly impossible.  Short of TS admitting he did it on purpose, it is 
highly unlikely to be proven.  In a sprint car, you maneuver just as much 
with the throttle as you do with the steering wheel, and to turn on a dirt 
track you absolutely need to apply the throttle.  Otherwise, the car will 
simply push the front tires across the dirt.  For those saying that TS 
"revved his engine" just prior to the impact, that is neither provable or 
disprovable, however it is likely he was on the throttle, since he was just 
coming out of a turn.  Either way, for anyone to say that TS did or did not 
do anything at all is mere speculation.  You can have an opinion or let 
your emotions cloud your judgement, but you'd only be guessing and hoping 
and wishing and wanting it to be one way or the other.  If you can prove 
something, I'm sure the investigators would love to hear from you... 
otherwise, pipe down!﻿

My heart and prayers go out to the Ward family and to Tony Stewart. I grew

their lives racing. I saw Mr. Vogler, Rich Volger's father, ran over by a

spinal injuries. This was a accident. These sprint cars have a wing on top 
of the rollcage and t...he driver's helmet is strapped to stay in place. 
With the wing and the helmet strapped, the driver has limited vision. They 
can not see what or who is on the side of them. They can only see in front 
of the car. USAC has rules that a driver has to stay with their car until 
the safety crew shows up. This was not a USAC race but it should be the 
rule for every racing group. This was a accident and we should all pray for 
those involved! Racing is a exciting but dangerous sport, I will always 
love it and I will always feel bad when we lose someone, but that is part

I have to agree with many of the others. Getting out of the car (under 
caution or not) is putting yourself in a hazardous situation. But then, 
when we add the fact that it is at night, which means visibility is less 
(yes, there were lights, but you still can't see as well as during the 
day), and the fact that he was wearing a black fire suit, which means he 
was even less visible, and the fact that, caution or not, these drivers 
aren't looking for PEDESTRIANS (If you see the video of the actual 
incident, rather than this CG reenactment, you will see that Ward comes 
DANGEROUSLY close to being hit by another car (which should be enough to 
tell someone, "Hey, maybe I should get out of the middle of the road!") but 
rather than learning from this, Ward apparently chooses to be the bad ass, 
and again, jumps into the path of Stewart's car. Notice, all the NASCAR 
guys wait until they're in the pits or the garage area, before they go 
attempting to confront another driver. There's a reason they don't do this 
in the middle of the track. Ward made a total rookie move, trying to make 
himself look like something, by calling out Tony Stewart, he made a string 
of poor decisions, and, in the end, it cost him his life.﻿
